meta_data.title: Act 2 of the Temple Rebuild
meta_data.subtitle: Ezra 3-4 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey, my friends, it's Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. And today we're going to build a temple. And by that, I mean, we're not going to do anything. We're not going to lift a finger. We're not going to do any of the temple building. We're not going to take any of the risks that these people took back in the day. I really know why I said it like that. I'm a little bit embarrassed, but now it's there and we're sticking with it. We're going to watch other people build a temple and vicariously experience that through them across the millennia. That would have been a better way to put it. We're looking at the three-act structure of the first half of the book of Ezra, where in Act I, well, before Act I, we get a little bit of a prologue, about Cyrus the Great. He's the great liberator of the people. In fact, there's even a Cyrus cylinder, a piece of propaganda that he put out that you can still see in the British Museum, where he says that he did this thing that's recorded in the Bible. I sent them home to rebuild their stuff. I'm this great liberator. It kind of was. I don't know. Is it bragging? If it's true, good for you, Cyrus. So we get past the prologue, then we get into Act I, which we looked at yesterday, which is mostly an introduction to how things were and the call to adventure and the people who went on the adventure and what we can learn about the adventure and what was anticipated based on who went on the trip. And then they get there and they're still in a good mood after their road trip and they donate a whole bunch of money and they start to conduct sacrifices under the leadership of the descendant of King David is a rubable. And then finally, we get to the place where the building actually starts. And the foundation of the temple gets put in place. And I would call this kind of the seam between the end of Act I and the beginning of Act II, because it's the first time we really run into a speed bump, a hurdle, not everything feels great as we get to the end of Act I, which I would say is the end of Ezra chapter three. And this difficult moment goes like this. It's the second month of the second year after the arrival back in Jerusalem according to Ezra three, eight. And according to verse 10, the builders laid the foundation of the temple of the Lord. And this is a huge deal, right? It's more than a groundbreaking ceremony. This should be the spike of the football moment, time to celebrate, but that isn't completely the vibe that we get here coming out of the end of Act I. So they decide we're gonna do a dedication. We need to celebrate and commemorate this moment. So the priests put on their vestments and with trumpets and the Levites, the sons of Asaph, remember the singers, the descendants of the psalmist, they show up with symbols and they took their places to praise the Lord as prescribed by David, king of Israel. So all of this stuff, I mean, the order of sacrifices, the rebuilding, the celebration and the dedication of all of this is all meant to harken back to better days. The last time there was some kind of unity and clarity of purpose on a grand scale among these people. I love what they're doing. And you can see the leadership and the character and the forethought and shrewdness of Zerubable on display here in how well handled all of this is. He gets it. And so this dedication of the foundation of the temple goes on verse 11 with praise and thanksgiving they sang to the Lord. He is good. His love to Israel endures forever. Even choosing to sing that is such a nod to, well, a lot of things that we don't have time to get into, but it's a nod to God's faithfulness, even in the face of his people's unfaithfulness and it goes on. And all the people gave a great shout of praise to the Lord because of the foundation of the house of the Lord was laid. You're probably going, okay, you said that at the end of act one, there's kind of a mixed bag. There's some emotional stuff here. This all just sounds great so far. Well, here's the part that I was teasing verse 12, but many of the older priests and Levites and family heads who had seen the former temple wept aloud when they saw the foundation of this temple being laid. While many others shouted for joy, no one could distinguish the sound of the shouts of joy from the sound of weeping because the people made so much noise and the sound was heard far away. End of act one, end of chapter three. So this is wild. There are some old timers there who still barely remember what Solomon's temple, the great temple looked like. And apparently this foundation has a much smaller footprint. The resources are smaller. It's not being built by a kingdom. It's being built by a conquered people group on a leash. It's a great opportunity. Yeah, but it's not happening under the same circumstances. And this smaller temple is reflective of the squandered opportunity. It's emblematic of what went wrong. It's a metaphor for the failures that landed the Jewish people in exile in the first place. And these older people tend to be more reflective than the rest of us anyway. They connect the dots on that and they feel the full emotion, I believe, here of the whole story. Whereas the younger people are like, we went on a trip. We did a thing. We're going to change the world. We got youthful exuberance. Everything's going to be great. I'm going to live forever. And so they're just celebrating like crazy. And it's a mixed bag. And I think everybody's doing what they ought to be doing. I think everyone is responding in the way that makes sense. But there's an ambiguity here. And we got that in Esther too, right? This axilic literature, Ezra, Nehemiah, and Esther, has these moments of ambiguity. Where you're like, huh, that's kind of a mixed bag. The reader is kind of allowed to not know exactly what to make of that. And here, I think it's a harbinger of one, real trouble and opposition that we're about to get to, that is to come and act two. And two, it's indicative that rebuilding the building isn't really the ultimate goal. It's very important, but rebuilding the people, as you and I have discussed so much already, that may be the bigger challenge than even putting this building back together. Because the fact that the original temple isn't standing there anymore is indicative of a litany of things that went wrong over the past several hundred years. And you can sack a lot of bricks on top of a lot of other bricks. You can find a way to raise the money to do that. But can you get the heart of the people in the right place and then figure out how to hand that down to ensuing generations so that you don't just build another building to get knocked over because you couldn't pass it along and you fail as a people down the road. So there's ambiguity here, there's tension that's being built, what's gonna happen in act two? Well, the quick version is this. At the beginning of act two, some enemies of Judah and Benjamin, this is the Jewish people who are back. They hear that there's gonna be a temple and so they show up, they go to Zerubbabel and they say, quote, verse two, let us help you build because like you, we seek your God and have been sacrificing to him since the time of Esher Adon, King of Assyria, who brought us here. And I don't know about you, but that exchange right there kind of reminds me of another moment in the Bible where a sort of Jew, but mostly ethnic outsider type comes along and says, I would want to worship this baby king of the Jews as well. Tell me where I could find him so that I could show up there totally not like swords or any kind of strangulation device. I wouldn't want to hurt a baby. What do you think I'm some kind of monster? Except Herod was a monster and he killed his own family of members and he was crazy. And as it turns out, right behind these smiles and ovations of friendliness and collegiality is the same kind of stuff. I'm not gonna criticize the Bible because it knows what it's doing. But this is one of those places here in Ezra 4 where our modern storytelling beats and rhythms and sensibilities are evidently very different than the storytelling sensibilities and beats of the fifth century BC because this jumps around a little bit and it gets confusing. And if you don't look closely, you don't catch that these guys really were enemies of Judah and Benjamin and that ultimately what they wanted to do was discourage and sabotage the rebuilding of the temple or worse yet, sabotage the rebuilding of the people which is the larger and more important quest. But we don't necessarily know why they're the enemies here on the front end. That becomes evident when Zerubbabel who was there and in the room and knows these people and sees what they're up to, rightly divines what their agenda is and tells them to pound sand. But Zerubbabel, Jeshua and the rest of the heads of the families of Israel answered, you have no part with us in building a temple to our God. We alone will build it for the Lord, the God of Israel as King Cyrus, the King of Persia, commanded us. Now part of this too, is that these people are showing up after the free will offering has already been given that was, what did we say that was again yesterday? After the whole crazy squirrel rabbit trail about the weight of ancient Persian coins, it wasn't like 30 million bucks or something. I don't remember, it was a crazy massive amount of money. And now right after that, these guys show up and are like, oh, we'd like the thing you've already paid for and then we'd like to have full ownership of it without kicking in. So I think there's that undertone as well. Now the cards are turned over. They know that Zerubbabel knows that they know and all the sides are clear and they begin to actively discourage the rebuilding of the temple, verse four. Then the peoples around them set out to discourage the people of Judah and make them afraid to go on building dang. So you got like political interference, you probably have some physical intimidation. They hired counselors to work against them and frustrate their plans during the entire reign of Cyrus King of Persia and down to the reign of Darius King of Persia. Now what happens here is from verse six on in the middle of act two here, we get the whole litany of things that happened that are all falling under the umbrella of the theme of resistance to the progress of the building of the temple and it takes us all the way from the reign of Cyrus into the reign of Darius, into the reign of Darius as Sun Xerxes. That's the king of the age of Esther and then down into the reign of Artaxerxes. And so what we're getting here is the author of Ezra, maybe Ezra himself, giving us this historical aside that takes us way into the future to say, this resistance wasn't just for a second, they resisted for a really long time and every king who sat on the throne, they would go and complain to and try to sabotage the Jewish people who are trying to rebuild the temple and rebuild their people and their relationship with God. Man, all of that is so interesting. I gave that pretty detailed coverage in my season two episode on the book of Ezra and then again at the beginning of the season three on the book of Esther. So if you wanna know more about how that timeline breaks down, you can go get that, but we will come back to this later on as we actually get into Nehemiah. Then at the end of Ezra chapter four, we come back out of that big historical aside that looks forward 75 years into the future that accounts for all the different layers of resistance and we come back to the moment in question during late in the reign of Cyrus and early in the reign of Darius. Well, the result of all of this resistance in the short term is this. Ezra 4, 24, thus the work on the house of God in Jerusalem came to a standstill until the second year of the reign of Darius, king of Persia. That's a long time. That means that basically nothing is getting done from somewhere in the mid-530s until the 519-ish BC. So as a point of comparison, based on when I'm recording this, that would be like we started work on a project in 2008 and then it sat there and nothing happened until right now. So that's sort of the end of act two. Now we have problems, there's meaningful resistance. I told you we were gonna get through the full building of a temple today. We did not, but we'll get act three next time around. Golly, I like doing this with you. Thanks for hanging out with me. I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
